##Strategy

Using the two equations, we can figure out if $\blueE {\text A}$ is leading (ahead of) or lagging (behind) with respect to $\redE {\text B}$. To do this, we need to look at the phase difference $\phi$ between the two equations.

In this case, if $\phi$ is positive, $\blueE {\text A}$ will be ahead. If $\phi$ is negative. $\blueE {\text A}$ will be behind.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Finally, using the magnitude of $\phi$, we can determine by how much is $\blueE {\text A}$ ahead of or behind $\redE {\text B}$.

options.explanation:
No! If $\blueE {\text A}$ was given by $\text{A}_0\ \cos(-\omega t)$ and $\redE {\text B}$ was given by $\text B_0 \cos(-\omega t + \phi)$, the situation would reverse. Then, a positive $\phi$ would indicate lagging and a negative $\phi$ would indicate leading. We can check this by graphing these functions.

Thus,

*Remember: Positive $\phi$ indicates leading and negative $\phi$ indicates lagging only when $\omega t$ is positive in the argument of $\cos$ or $\sin$.*

hints.content:
##Solution

__Identifying if $\blueE {\text A}$ is leading or lagging. __

Looking at the two equations, we can identify the phases of $\blueE {\text A}$ and $\redE {\text B}$, $\delta_A$ and $\delta_B$.

 $\redE {\text B}=\text{B}_0\cos(\underbrace{\omega t}_{\delta_B})$ and $\blueE {\text A}=\text A_0\cos(\underbrace{\omega t+\dfrac{\pi}{4}}_{\delta_A})$. 

We can see that $\delta_A > \delta_B$, so $\blueE {\text A}$ must be leading (ahead of) $\redE {\text B}$.

The magnitude of phase difference, $\phi=\delta_A-\delta_B=\dfrac{\pi}{4}$. In terms of time period, this corresponds to a time difference of $\dfrac{\text T}{8}$.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Thus, $\blueE {\text A}$ is ahead of $\redE {\text B}$ by $\dfrac{\text T}{8}$. This means $\blueE {\text A}$ attains its zero, minimum and maximum time $\dfrac{\text T}{8}$ before $\redE {\text B}$. Looking at the options, there's only one curve where $\blueE {\text A}$ is ahead of $\redE {\text B}$ with this time difference.

[[☃ image 1]]

We can see above that $\blueE {\text A}$ reaches zero at $\text T/8$, while $\redE {\text B}$ reaches zero at ${\text T}/{4}$. So $\blueE {\text A}$ is ahead by $\Delta t=\dfrac{\text T}{4} - \dfrac{\text T}{8} = \dfrac{\text T}{8}$.

options.explanation:
The time difference, let's call it $\Delta t$ and the phase difference $\phi$ are related as given below.

$\begin{align}
\phi &=\maroonD \omega \tealE {\Delta t} \\\\
\Rightarrow \tealE{\Delta t}&= \dfrac{\phi}{\maroonD {\omega}}\\\\
&= \dfrac{\dfrac{\pi}{4}}{\maroonD {\dfrac{2\pi}{\text T}}}\\\\
&=\dfrac{\text T}{8}
\end{align}$
